They also acquired fluorescence spectra from non-diabetic individuals (healthy controls) for comparison. The researchers observed that the fluorescence emission intensity at 450 nm increased with increasing glucose concentration in urine. Additionally, they used optimized synchronous fluorescence emission at 357 nm to determine the level of tryptophan (Trp) in urine, which is a potential diabetes biomarker. They found that the level of tryptophan decreased with increasing urinary glucose concentration. The researchers quantitatively estimated urinary glucose based on the intensity of emission light carried by fluorescence.
